Standard Text: Select and operate appropriate software to perform a variety of tasks, and recognize that users have different needs and preferences for the technology they use.
Students should be able to select the appropriate app/program to use for tasks they are required to complete.
With teacher guidance, students should compare and discuss preferences for software with the same primary functionality.
Use appropriate terminology in identifying and describing the function of common physical components of computing systems (hardware).
Students should be able to identify and describe the function of external hardware, such as desktop computers, laptop computers, tablet devices, monitors, keyboards, mice, and printers.
Describe basic hardware and software problems using accurate terminology.
Students should be able to communicate a problem with accurate terminology (e.g., when an app or program is not working as expected, a device will not turn on, the sound does not work, etc.).
Explain what passwords are and why we use them.
Students should understand that computers connect them to people, places, and things around the world.
Store, copy, search, retrieve, modify, and delete information using a computing device and define the information stored as data.
Students should be able to manipulate data through their use of software to complete tasks on a computing device.
Collect and present the same data in various visual formats.
Students should be able to collect data.
Students should be able to present data in various visual formats.
Identify and describe patterns in data visualizations, such as charts or graphs, to make predictions.
Students should be able to analyze data in visual formats.
Students should be able to identify patterns and make predictions based on  the patterns.
Model daily processes by creating and following algorithms (sets of step-by-step instructions) to complete tasks.
Students should be able to create and follow algorithms.
Model the way programs store and manipulate data by using numbers or other symbols to represent information.
Students should be able to model data storage and manipulation by using representative symbols.
Develop programs with sequences and simple loops to express ideas or address a problem.
Students should be able to express ideas or address problems by developing programs with sequences and simple loops.
Decompose (break down) the steps needed to solve a problem into a precise sequence of instructions.
Students should be able to break down the steps needed to solve a problem into a precise sequence of instructions.
Develop plans that describe a program’s sequence of events, goals, and expected outcomes.
Students should be able to develop and visually illustrate the plan for what a program will do.
Give attribution when using the ideas and creations of others while developing programs.
Students should credit artifacts that were created by others, such as pictures, music, and code.
Debug (identify and fix) errors in an algorithm or program that includes sequences and simple loops.

Students should be able to use various strategies, such as changing the sequence of the steps, following the algorithm in a step-by-step manner, or trial and error to fix problems in algorithms and programs.
Using correct terminology, describe steps taken and choices made during the iterative process of program development.
Students should be able to talk or write about the goals and expected outcomes of the programs they create and the choices that they made when creating programs.
Compare how people live and work before and after the implementation or adoption of new computing technology.
Students should be able to compare how people live and work before and after the implementation or adoption of new computing technology.
Work respectfully and responsibly with others online.
Students should demonstrate understanding of how to work with others online in a respectful and responsibly way.
Students should be able to identify cyberbullying.
Keep login information private and log off of devices appropriately.
Students should understand that some things like login details, their address, and other personally identifying information is private (secret).
Students should know to always log off properly on any device used.
Describe how internal and external parts of computing devices function to form a  system.
Students should describe how devices and components interact using correct terminology.
Model how computer hardware and software work together as a system to accomplish tasks.
Students should model how computer hardware and software work together to accomplish tasks.
Determine potential solutions to solve simple hardware and software problems using common troubleshooting strategies.
Students should be able to identify common hardware and software problems.
Students should identify and implement various troubleshooting strategies.
Model how information is broken down into smaller pieces, transmitted as packets through multiple devices over networks and the Internet, and reassembled at the  destination.
Students should demonstrate their understanding of how information flows over networks and the Internet.
Discuss real-world cybersecurity problems and how personal information can be protected.
Students should be able to explain what passwords are and why we use them, and use strong passwords to protect devices and information from unauthorized access.
Students should be able to list several real-world cybersecurity issues and discuss how personal information can be protected.
Organize and present collected data visually to highlight relationships and support a claim.
Students should be able to collect data and present the information in an organized way to highlight relationships and support a claim.
Use data to highlight or propose cause-and-effect relationships, predict outcomes, or communicate an idea.
Students should be able to refer to data to highlight or propose cause-and effect relationships and predict outcomes when communicating an idea.
Store, copy, search, retrieve, modify, and delete information using a computing device and define the information stored as data.
Students should be able to manipulate data through their use of software to complete tasks on a computing device.
Compare and refine multiple algorithms for the same task and determine which is the most appropriate.
Students should be able to look at different ways to solve the same task and decide which would be the best solution.
Create programs that use variables to store and modify data.
Students should understand how to use variables to store and modify data.
Create programs that include sequences, events, loops, and conditionals.
Students should be able to create programs that include sequences, events, loops, and conditionals.
Decompose (break down) problems into smaller, manageable subproblems to facilitate the program development process.
Students should be able to break down problems into smaller, simpler tasks.
Modify, remix, or incorporate portions of an existing program into one's own work to develop something new or add more advanced features.
Students should be able to modify and/or reuse portions of an existing  program into their own work to create something new.
Use an iterative process to plan the development of a program by including others' perspectives and considering user preferences.
Students outline key features, time and resource constraints, and user expectations.
Students should document the plan as, for example, a storyboard, flowchart, pseudocode, or story map.
Observe intellectual property rights and give appropriate attribution when creating or remixing programs.
Students should identify instances of remixing, when ideas are borrowed and iterated upon, and credit the original creator.
Students should also consider common licenses that place limitations or restrictions on the use of computational artifacts, such as images and music downloaded from the Internet.
Test and debug (identify and fix errors) a program or algorithm to ensure it runs as intended.
Students should be able to identify and debug simple errors in programs they create and in programs created by others.
Take on varying roles, with teacher guidance, when collaborating with peers during  the design, implementation, and review stages of program development.
Students should take turns in different roles during program development,  such as note taker, facilitator, program tester, or “driver” of the computer.
Describe choices made during program development using code comments,  presentations, and demonstrations.
Students should explain code choices using comments within the code,  presentations, and demonstrations.
Discuss computing technologies that have changed the world and express how those  technologies influence and are influenced by cultural practices.
Students, with guidance from their teacher, should discuss topics that relate to  the history of technology and the changes in the world due to technology.
Seek diverse perspectives for the purpose of improving computational artifacts.
Students will collaborate and receive feedback from others.
Use public domain or creative commons media and refrain from copying or using  material created by others without permission.
Students should consider the licenses on computational artifacts that they wish  to use.
Recommend improvements to the design of computing devices based on an analysis  of how users interact with the devices.
Students should make recommendations for existing devices (e.g., a laptop,  phone, or tablet) or design their own components or interface (e.g., create their own controllers).
Design projects that combine hardware and software components to collect and  exchange data.
Students will design projects that use both hardware and software to collect  and exchange data.
Systematically identify and fix problems with computing devices and their  components.
Students will use a structured process to troubleshoot problems with computing systems and ensure that potential solutions are not overlooked.
Model the role of protocols in transmitting data across networks and the Internet.
Students should model how data is sent using protocols to choose the fastest  path, to deal with missing information, and to deliver sensitive data securely.
Explain how physical and digital security measures protect electronic information.
Students will explain how physical and digital security measures protect  electronic information.
Apply multiple methods of encryption to model the secure transmission of  information.
Students should encode and decode messages using a variety of encryption  methods, and they should understand the different levels of complexity used to hide or secure information.
Represent data using multiple encoding schemes.
Students should represent the same data in multiple ways.
Collect data using computational tools and transform the data to make it more useful  and reliable.
Students should transform data to remove errors, highlight or expose  relationships, and/or make it easier for computers to process.
Refine computational models based on the data they have generated.
Students will refine computational models by considering which data points  are relevant, how data points relate to each other, and if the data is accurate.
Use flowcharts and/or pseudocode to address complex problems as algorithms.
Students will use pseudocode and/or flowcharts to organize and sequence an  algorithm that addresses a complex problem, even though they may not actually program the solutions.
Create clearly named variables that represent different data types and perform  operations on their values.
When planning and developing programs, students should decide when and  how to declare and name new variables.
Students should use naming conventions to improve program readability.
Design and iteratively develop programs that combine control structures, including  nested loops and compound conditionals.
Students will design and develop programs that combine control structures.
Decompose problems and subproblems into parts to facilitate the design,  implementation, and review of programs.
Students should break down problems into subproblems, which can be further  broken down to smaller parts.
Create procedures with parameters to organize code and make it easier to reuse.
Students will create procedures and/or functions that are used multiple times  within a program to repeat groups of instructions.
Seek and incorporate feedback from team members and users to refine a solution  that meets user needs.
Students should begin to seek diverse perspectives throughout the design  process to improve their computational artifacts.
Incorporate existing code, media, and libraries into original programs and give  attribution.
Students should use portions of code, algorithms, and/or digital media in their  own programs and websites.
Students should give attribution to the original creator’s contributions.
Systematically test and refine programs using a range of test cases.
Students will test programs by considering potential errors, such as what will  happen if a user enters invalid input (e.g., negative numbers and zero instead of positive numbers).
Distribute tasks and maintain a project timeline when collaboratively developing  computational artifacts.
Students will work collaboratively in groups.
Students should assume predefined roles within their teams and manage the  project workflow using structured timelines.
Students should give attribution to the original creators to acknowledge their  contributions.
Document programs in order to make them easier to follow, test, and debug.
Students should provide documentation for end users that explains their  artifacts and how they function.
Students should incorporate comments in their product (comments in the  code).
Students should communicate their process using design documents,  flowcharts, and presentations.
Compare tradeoffs associated with computing technologies that affect people's  everyday activities and career options.
Students should consider current events related to broad ideas, including  privacy, communication, and automation.
Discuss issues of bias and accessibility in the design of existing technologies.
Students should test and discuss the usability of various technology tools (e.g.,  apps, games, and devices) with the teacher's guidance.
Collaborate with many contributors through strategies such as crowdsourcing or  surveys when creating a computational artifact.
Students should collaborate with many contributors.
Describe tradeoffs between allowing information to be public and keeping  information private and secure.
Students should discuss and describe the benefits and dangers of allowing  information to be public or kept private and secure.
Use flowcharts and/or pseudocode to address complex problems as algorithms.
Students will use pseudocode and/or flowcharts to organize and sequence an  algorithm that addresses a complex problem, even though they may not actually program the solutions.
Create clearly named variables that represent different data types and perform  operations on their values.
When planning and developing programs, students should decide when and  how to declare and name new variables.
Students should use naming conventions to improve program readability.
Decompose problems and subproblems into parts to facilitate the design,  implementation, and review of programs.
Students should break down problems into subproblems, which can be further  broken down to smaller parts.
Create procedures with parameters to organize code and make it easier to reuse.
Students will create procedures and/or functions that are used multiple times  within a program to repeat groups of instructions.
Seek and incorporate feedback from team members and users to refine a solution  that meets user needs.
Students should begin to seek diverse perspectives throughout the design  process to improve their computational artifacts.
Incorporate existing code, media, and libraries into original programs and give  attribution.
Students should use portions of code, algorithms, and/or digital media in their  own programs and websites.
Students should give attribution to the original creator’s contributions.
Systematically test and refine programs using a range of test cases.
Students will test programs by considering potential errors, such as what will  happen if a user enters invalid input (e.g., negative numbers and zero instead of positive numbers).
Distribute tasks and maintain a project timeline when collaboratively developing  computational artifacts.
Students will work collaboratively in groups.
Students should assume predefined roles within their teams and manage the  project workflow using structured timelines.
Students should give attribution to the original creators to acknowledge their  contributions.

Students should provide documentation for end users that explains their  artifacts and how they function.
Students should incorporate comments in their product (comments in the  code).
Students should communicate their process using design documents,  flowcharts, and presentations.
Discuss issues of bias and accessibility in the design of existing technologies.
Use flowcharts and/or pseudocode to address complex problems as algorithms.
Students will use pseudocode and/or flowcharts to organize and sequence an  algorithm that addresses a complex problem, even though they may not actually program the solutions.
Create clearly named variables that represent different data types and perform  operations on their values.
When planning and developing programs, students should decide when and  how to declare and name new variables.
Project Name: 2.4 I Want It, I Bought It

Students should incorporate comments in their product (comments in the  code).
Students should communicate their process using design documents,  flowcharts, and presentations.
Compare tradeoffs associated with computing technologies that affect people's  everyday activities and career options.
Students should consider current events related to broad ideas, including  privacy, communication, and automation.
Discuss issues of bias and accessibility in the design of existing technologies.
Students should test and discuss the usability of various technology tools (e.g.,  apps, games, and devices) with the teacher's guidance.
Collaborate with many contributors through strategies such as crowdsourcing or  surveys when creating a computational artifact.
Students should collaborate with many contributors.
Explain how abstractions hide the underlying implementation details of computing  systems embedded in everyday objects.
Students should be able to identify embedded computer systems.
Students should describe the types of data and procedures that are included in  the embedded system and explain how the implementation details are hidden
Compare levels of abstraction and interactions between application software, system  software, and hardware layers.
Students should be able to distinguish between hardware and software.
Students should be able to describe the purpose of and differences between  system software (i.e. operating system) and application software (i.e. word processor).
Students should be able to describe how software and hardware interact.
Develop guidelines that convey systematic troubleshooting strategies that others can  use to identify and fix errors.
Students should develop guidelines by creating an artifact that conveys  systematic troubleshooting strategies (i.e. create a flow chart or a job aid for a help desk employee).
Evaluate the scalability and reliability of networks by describing the relationship  between routers, switches, servers, topology, and addressing.
Students should be able to explain what a router and a switch are and how  they work inside a network.
Students should be able to define what a server is and how it is used in a  network.
Students should be able to list various types of network topology and explain  why each is used.
Students should be able to verbally and visually explain how addressing,  routers, switches, and servers all work together in a network.
Give examples to illustrate how sensitive data can be affected by malware and other  attacks.
Students should be able to discuss how sensitive data can be affected by  malware and other attacks.
Recommend security measures to address various scenarios based on factors such as  efficiency, feasibility, and ethical impacts.
Students should understand the different types of security problems and the  different types of devices that can be impacted.
Students should systematically evaluate different security measures based on  efficiency, feasibility, and ethical impacts.
Compare various security measures considering tradeoffs between the usability and  security of a computing system.
Students should be able to explain different types of security measures and  discuss the tradeoffs between usability and security.
Explain tradeoffs when selecting and implementing cybersecurity recommendations.
Students should be able to describe, justify, and document choices they make  using terminology appropriate for the intended audience and purpose.
Translate between different bit representations of real-world phenomena, such as  characters, numbers, and images.
Students should be able to translate between different bit representations.
Students should be able to discuss how data sequences can be interpreted in a  variety of formats.
Collect, transform, and organize data to help others better understand a problem.
Students should use various data collection techniques for different types of  computational problems.
Use computational tools to collect, transform, and organize data to help others  better understand a problem.
Students should use data analysis to identify significant patterns in data sets.
Create and evaluate computational models that represent real-world systems.
Students should create computational models that simulate real-world  systems (e.g., ecosystems, epidemics, spread of disease).
Students should analyze and evaluate the ability of models and simulations to  formulate, refine, and test hypothesis.
Create prototypes that use algorithms to solve computational problems by leveraging  prior student knowledge and personal interests.
Students create artifacts that are personally relevant or beneficial to their  community and beyond.
Use lists and functions to simplify solutions, generalizing computational problems  instead of repeatedly using simple variables.
Students should be able to identify common features in multiple segments of  code and substitute a single segment that uses lists (arrays) or functions to account for the differences.
Justify the selection of specific control structures when tradeoffs involve  implementation, readability, and program performance, and explain the benefits and  drawbacks of choices made.
Students should be able to justify by explaining the benefits and drawbacks of  the selection of specific control structures with regard to implementation, readability, and program performance.
Design and iteratively develop computational artifacts for practical intent, personal  expression, or to address a societal issue by using events to initiate instructions.
Students will design procedures that are called by events.
Decompose problems into smaller components through systematic analysis, using  constructs such as procedures, modules, and/or objects.
Students should decompose complex problems into manageable subproblems that could potentially be solved with programs or procedures that already exist.
Create artifacts by using procedures within a program, combinations of data and  procedures, or independent but interrelated programs.
Students will create artifacts by using procedures within a program,  combinations of data, and procedures, or independent but interrelated programs.
Systematically design and develop programs for broad audiences by incorporating  feedback from users.
Students should do so through a systematic process that includes feedback  from broad audiences.
Evaluate licenses that limit or restrict use of computational artifacts when using  resources such as libraries.
Students should consider licensing implications for their own work, especially  when incorporating libraries and other resources.
Evaluate and refine computational artifacts to make them more usable and  accessible.
Students should respond to the changing needs and expectations of end users  and improve the performance, reliability, usability, and accessibility of artifacts.
Design and develop computational artifacts working in team roles using collaborative  tools.
Students will work in teams using collaborative tools to design and develop  computational artifacts.
Document design decisions using text, graphics, presentations, and/or  demonstrations in the development of complex programs.
Students will document design decisions using text, graphics, presentations,  and/or demonstrations.
Evaluate the ways computing impacts personal, ethical, social, economic, and cultural  practices.
Students should be able to evaluate the accessibility of a product to a broad  group of end users, such as people who lack access to broadband or who have various disabilities.
Students should also begin to identify potential bias during the design process  to maximize accessibility in product design.
Test and refine computational artifacts to reduce bias and equity deficits.

Students should begin to identify potential bias during the design process to  maximize accessibility in product design and become aware of professionally accepted accessibility standards to evaluate computational artifacts for accessibility.
Demonstrate ways a given algorithm applies to problems across disciplines.
Students should be able to identify real-world problems that span multiple  disciplines, such as increasing bike safety with new helmet technology, and that can be solved computationally.
Use tools and methods for collaboration on a project to increase connectivity of  people in different cultures and career fields.
Students should explore different collaborative tools and methods used to  solicit input from team members, classmates, and others, such as participation in online forums or local communities.
Create prototypes that use algorithms to solve computational problems by leveraging  prior student knowledge and personal interests.
Students create artifacts that are personally relevant or beneficial to their  community and beyond.
Use lists and functions to simplify solutions, generalizing computational problems  instead of repeatedly using simple variables.
Students should be able to identify common features in multiple segments of  code and substitute a single segment that uses lists (arrays) or functions to account for the differences.

Students will design procedures that are called by events.

Students should decompose complex problems into manageable subproblems that could potentially be solved with programs or procedures that already exist.
Create artifacts by using procedures within a program, combinations of data and  procedures, or independent but interrelated programs.
Students will create artifacts by using procedures within a program,  combinations of data, and procedures, or independent but interrelated programs.
Systematically design and develop programs for broad audiences by incorporating  feedback from users.
Students should do so through a systematic process that includes feedback  from broad audiences.
Evaluate licenses that limit or restrict use of computational artifacts when using  resources such as libraries.
Students should consider licensing implications for their own work, especially  when incorporating libraries and other resources.
Evaluate and refine computational artifacts to make them more usable and  accessible.
Students should respond to the changing needs and expectations of end users  and improve the performance, reliability, usability, and accessibility of artifacts.
Design and develop computational artifacts working in team roles using collaborative  tools.
Students will work in teams using collaborative tools to design and develop  computational artifacts.
Document design decisions using text, graphics, presentations, and/or  demonstrations in the development of complex programs.
Students will document design decisions using text, graphics, presentations,  and/or demonstrations.
Create prototypes that use algorithms to solve computational problems by leveraging  prior student knowledge and personal interests.
Project Name: 2.4 I Want It, I Bought It
